Yes, the statement can be translated into a formal logical system using propositional logic and quantifiers. Here is one way to represent it in symbolic form:
```less
∀x(P(russia) ∧ x < n)(R(x)) → (∃y(P(russia) ∧ y > n))
```
where `P` represents the proposition "has visited Russia", `n` represents the number of people who have not visited Russia, `x` represents an arbitrary person, `R(x)` represents the fact that `x` has visited Russia, and `y` represents another arbitrary person. The arrow (`→`) indicates implication. This formula means that for all persons `x`, if they have visited Russia and there are fewer such persons than `n`, then there exists at least one other person `y` who has also visited Russia but there are more such persons than `n`. In this case, we could set `n = 100` and say that more than 100 people have visited Russia than you have.
